snippet: Following a scathing British parliamentary report declaring Rupert Murdoch unfit to run a media empire, BSkyB insisted on Wednesday that its own track record should determine fitness to hold a broadcasting license.
abstract: Britain’s biggest satellite broadcaster, British Sky Broadcasting, or BSkyB, distances itself from its largest shareholder, Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, in a sign of the difficulties he faces following a scathing parliamentary report that declared him not fit to run a global media empire.

byline.original: By SARAH LYALL and AMY CHOZICK
byline.contributor: Sarah Lyall reported from London, and Amy Chozick from New York. Julia Werdigier contributed reporting from London, and Alan Cowell from Paris.

lead_paragraph: Following a scathing British parliamentary report declaring Rupert Murdoch unfit to run a media empire, BSkyB insisted on Wednesday that its own track record should determine fitness to hold a broadcasting license.

headline.seo: BSkyB Distances Itself From Murdoch and News Corporation
headline.main: Britain’s Biggest Satellite Broadcaster Distances Itself From Murdoch
headline.print_headline: Britain’s Biggest Satellite Broadcaster Distances Itself From Murdoch
